last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15007842
I went to graduate school in America after getting my bachelor's. You can go directly from your bachelor's (a 4 year degree post primary school) to a PhD program. You still have to apply to schools so while it's not required in most programs, you can argue it looks better when you apply to have had a masters prior. Often, many students (particularly in engineering) will do a 5 years master program where the student will simultaneously pursue their bachelor's and masters in 5 years (as opposed to the 4 + 2 years it typically takes in America). PhD program lengths vary (usually being heavily dependent on the student's own motivation and the PI's willingness to let the candidate graduate), but typically takes about 3-6 years.

I am not familiar with the funding rates for mathematics, so I can't speak specifically for that but I do know that universities in America will give funding preference to PhD students over masters students. In engineering, the it's very common that PhD students will be fully funded (tuition + an annual stipend). Most PIs will ask students to seek external funding sources as part of their first year or 2 in the lab (national grants for example) so they can get off the college/department funding vehicle - typically being incentivized with x% of dollars saved as kickback funding to the lab.

>>15012237

The good news is it's manageable.

Write down all tasks you're planning or worry about (no exceptions) on a piece of paper you can put in your pocket. Record all commitments in a calendar, with frequent reminders for each. Keep your working area completely clean, both physically and digitally (desktop icons hidden, windows maximized). Record any tasks you think of immediately, and return to what you were doing. Revisit your list to pick which tasks you'll attempt at the beginning of each day. Live a life of minimalism, otherwise everything will feel like an endless mess of things to organize and clean. Etc, you get the idea.

You have to put these structures in place as soon as you can and stick to them for the rest of your life.

Read the original GTD book by David Allen. That is, if the disorder hasn't completely compromised your reading ability.

I swore off drugs too (prescription stimulants) until I had exhausted every other option, which was a serious mistake. My life would have been much less stressful and far more fulfilling had I been medicated sooner. Just my experience tho, like >>15012660 you can always try them and stop them when you want, unlike with antidepressents.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Infinite sets don't exist or don't have a cardinality
threads.com:
The idea that two infinite sets can have the same cardinality because you can establish a one-to-one correspondence between its members is contradictory since you can also establish a one-to-every-two correspondence, a one-to-every-three, ... , one-to-every-n correspondence. All of which would tell you the two sets have different cardinalities because guess what, since the set isn't finite, you don't know what the last number is, hence you can't really say by mapping one element to every other element you will be able to map all elements or not.

For example, take the set of even natural numbers E and the set of natural numbers N. Set theory books would have you believe that because you can connect the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, that means you established a one-to-one correspondence, and so E and N must have the same cardinality. The problem is that you don't really know if you really able to do that for all elements since you don't know what the last element is. Further, since cardinality is a determined size, an infinite set cannot possible have a cardinality, thus leading to contradictions if you try to compare their non-existence cardinalities as you shall soon see.

Now, instead of mapping the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, map the 1st element of E with the 2nd element of N, the 2nd of E with the 4th of N, the 3rd element of E with the 6th element of N, and so on. By the same reasoning of the "same cardinality via one-to-one correspondence", this should lead you to conclude that E has half the cardinality of N.

>>15013132
The simple abstraction of chromosomes being deterministic of secondary sex characteristics isn't accurate

Actually, most of these traits such as muscle mass, deepness of voice, body hair, etc are epigenetic traits in which the expression of genetic potential is modified by environmental factors.

The combination of environmental contaminants such as onions proteins and microplastics in the modern world, passive environmental conditions like a sedentary lifestyle and high screen time, and psychosocial factors such as underdeveloped social skills and ubiquitous feminist and pro-queer values systems can often reshape the expression of secondary sex characteristics to more closely resemble those of the opposite biological sex.

As a mental health diagnosis, it isn't clearly defined and certainly isn't the absolute material state of "being the opposite gender" based solely on personal declaration that it gets socially celebrated as. But yes, the biological basis of a dramatically increasing number of people developing intermediate expression of secondary sex characteristics does actually exist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15011412
X: # rotten fruits
Y: # total fruits
P(random fruit f is rotten): (P(random rotten fruit is f)*X)/(P(random fruit is f)*Y)

So
P(random W is rotten) = (.52/.13)*(X/Y)
P(random A is rotten) = (.24/.69)*(X/Y)
P(W_r)/P(A_r) = (.52*.69)/(.13*.24) = 11.5

So a randomly chosen watermelon is 11.5 times more likely to be rotten than a randomly chosen apple.

>>15012697
could neutrino detections be neutrons accelerated to relativistic speeds that substantially slow their decay through time dilation? maybe if the neutron is a composite particle, the linear acceleration could reach a point where the destabilization of the system that causes the decay of free neutrons is somehow stabilized by the magnetic field created by each particle's motion - maybe fast enough neutrons could be magnetically bound instead of electrostatically bound?

i have no real beef with the standard model of particle physics, but i do worry that having a standard model leads to far, far too quick dismissal of ideas that may lead to a better model - logically speaking, if the existing models have contradictions, it means that any "truer" model necessarily must be incompatible with those models. using the model as a litmus test for its own alternatives is holding us back, i think, and making it much more likely that in desperation to correct the contradictions we'll spend huge efforts on formulating ever more complex and ever more meaningless unfalsifiable abstractions to avoid stepping on the assumptions we forgot the model was making in the first place (*cough* string theory *cough*).

https://mysteriesrunsolved.com/mt/2021/01/missing-supermassive-black-hole.html

Scientist believes that a supermassive black hole is at the center of galaxy with a mass that is millions or billions of times that of the Sun and that its enormous gravitational force is responsible for keeping all the stars inna galaxy together.

However, the core of the galaxy cluster Abell 2261, located about 2.7 billion light-years from Earth, appears to disprove the theory.

There, the rules of astrophysics indicate that there should be a huge black monster of between 3,000 and 100,000 million solar masses, comparable to the weight of some of the largest known. However, no matter how many times researchers search relentlessly, there is no way to find it.

The latest observations with NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Hubble Space Telescope only delve into the mystery.

Astronomers have found no definitive evidence of black hole recovery, and it is unknown if the supermassives get close enough to produce gravitational waves and merge. So far, they have only verified the collapse of much smaller objects. The discovery of a larger one that recedes encourages scientists to search for gravitational waves from merging supermassive black holes.

During a merger, the supermassive black hole in each galaxy descends toward the center of the recently merged galaxy. If they are held together by gravity and their orbit begins to shrink, the black holes are expected to interact with surrounding stars and expel them from the center of the galaxy. This explains the large core of Abell 2261.

The authors concluded that either there is no black hole in any of these places, or that it is attracting material too slowly to produce a detectable X-ray signal.

Regarding clinical trials to develop a new drug:
Why do they take so long ?
Why do they cost so much ?
Can AI help speed things up ?
Can anything else help speed things up other than just pouring more money in ?

From a number of sources, the common length of a clinical trial is about 7 years. Some are very short, only a few months, but most are at least 5 years, right up to over 15 years.

The cost of developing a drug is typically over $1 billion dollars, sometimes over $2 billion
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_drug_development

The strangest thing to me I think is the administration costs, they're usually about 20%. That's about $200 million just for admin, about $30 million per year. Say each employee is making $100k/yr, that's 300 employees, that doesn't sound right. Obviously there might be other costs involved in that, but even 150 employees sounds like too much. The patients they trial the drugs on are usually only paid a few hundred dollars too, and there's only maybe 20 to 30 of them, so $30k

I get the feeling a lot of money is wasted in these trials and they could probably be significantly streamlined. The admin costs almost seem like it's a way for pharmaceutical companies to launder large amounts of cash or something

1^inf equals 1, but typically you end up with 1^inf by solving a limit n->+inf f(n)^g(n), where the base approaches 1 and the exponent approaches inf. f(n)^inf differs in the cases where f=1 and f is just very close to 1, and we discard the nature of the approaches of f and g by naively calculating the limit. Hence the limit is undefined and needs more work.

last_replies.name: 24d18a4cf585d05340b4debe4e67
last_replies.com:
>>15009878
Good question.

Let us consider an innovation. It is characterised by its effect on a system.

A system is a directed weighted graph. The nodes are subsystems (e.g. humans. I can't think of any other example) and the edges are control over another node.

A good innovation does not destroy the system. When does the system break down? When the control-dampening elements (edge-weight<1) are weaker than the control-amplifying elements (edge-weight>1) globally (so exercising power just gets too easy for everyone and statistically speaking you enter the chaotic domain).
And how does innovation destroy the system? By increasing the control of individuals over other nodes (this is the essence of the phrase "knowledge is power").

In the case of a static system/graph a maximum degree of knowledge before certain collapse would exist.
However systems (the graph) change and adapt. If you increase the global control the graphs get bigger and the nodes grow more distant again and the systems morph to fit to the changed power over a long time.
So you see: The actual limit of technological progress should just not break the system we call human society.

Also note how I imply systems can be reduced to a monad which we do not need to understand because we are just taking a global information theoretical viewpoint.

last_replies.com:
Distance between foci is 2*sqrt(b^2-a^2) (basic ellipse fact)

4(b^2-a^2) = (2a^2/b)^2
a^4 + a^2*b^2 - b^4 = 0

Solve quadratic

a = b * sqrt((sqrt(5)-1)/2) =: bC

Make coordinate system with O at origin, parameterize ellipse as

x = a cos(t)
y = b sin(t)

At corners of the trapezoid y/x = (b/a) tan(t) = tan(180-75/2) =: D

t = arctan(a/b*D)+180 (add 180 to adjust for the correct quadrant)
y = b sin(arctan(a/b*D)+180)
= -aD/sqrt((aD/b)^2+1)
= -b CD/sqrt((CD)^2+1)

Right base = 2y = -2b CD/sqrt((CD)^2+1) = bE
Left base = altitude = 2a^2/b
Area of trapezoid = 1/2*(bE+2a^2/b)*2a^2/b = (E+2C^2)(bC)^2
Area of ellipse = pi*a*b = pi*C*b^2

With
b = 100
C = sqrt((sqrt(5)-1)/2) ~= 0.786
D = tan(180-75/2) ~= -0.767
E = -2CD/sqrt((CD)^2+1) ~= 1.033

Area of trapezoid = 14024
Area of ellipse = 24698

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15010473
You know, scientists actually don't know. The traditional non rotating black holes everyone learns about in pop sci probably don't exist. It difficult to imagine a gravitationally bound object not having angular momentum from its formation. Ringularities have two horizons for which the inner covers another ergosphere. Since ergospheres can accelerate mass faster than light, it's not impossible that you can leave a black hole. Penrose diagrams show the exit of a black hole would put you in a universe that isn't the one you came from. It would look like you would emerge from a white hole but with the unlikely exception of the big bang, such objects don't exist.

Just keep in mind that the radiation from the accretion disk would vaporize you long before you ever got close to the event horizon so suffice to say, any discussion of near or in can only be a mathematical depictions.
